thread.title: Clinton claims status as political 'outsider' because she's a woman
thread.title_full: Clinton claims status as political 'outsider' because she's a woman | Washington Examiner

author: Pete Kasperowicz
title: Clinton claims status as political 'outsider' because she's a woman
text:
Even though Democratic front-runner Hillary Clinton is a former first lady and a former U.S. senator, she cast herself as a political outsider on Monday because she's a woman.
"Who can be more of an outsider than a woman president?" she said on NBC's "Today Show."
Anchor Savannah Guthrie seemed to agree by saying to Clinton that "one of your merits is that you're a woman," and asked her how a female leader would run the White House differently.
"We have a very different life experience, I think it's fair to say," she said to applause.
  'Citizen Carly': Super PAC unveils new documentary 
CARLY for America, a super PAC supporting Carly Fiorina's presidential campaign, unveiled a new feature-length video detailing the candidate's life story. The video, titled "Citizen Carly," aims to push back against criticism that cast doubt on her claim of rising from "secretary to CEO."
"This is the true and full story," said Stephen DeMaura, executive director of the PAC, in a statement touting the super PAC's film last month. "Not through the lens of liberal reporters, but through the lens of the people who have known her for decades."
The video has already received praise from right-leaning columnists, including Legal Insurrection's Amy Miller who called it a "big F- You" to those who viewed her rise from secretary to
By Ryan Lovelace • 10/05/15 11:29 AM "I think that, you know, a lot of my agenda about how do we support families, and how do we support working women, how do we get paid family leave, how do we do caregiving?" she added. "I was just talking to one of the people here, we're going to have a huge challenge on helping to take care of people with Alzheimer's, people who are getting older with Autism and a lot of other conditions."
"We live that in a much more real, you know, day to day way, and I will bring all of those, you know, feelings and experiences with me to the White House," she said.
